summary: A character reference letter addressed to Judge Alison J. Nathan in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's bail application. The writer, a long-time friend, describes Maxwell's positive personal qualities, philanthropic work, and argues she is not a flight risk, offering to sign a $5 million bond.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The Honorable judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York to whom this character reference letter for Ghislaine Maxwell is addressed.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the character reference letter. The writer describes her as a vivacious, intelligent, principled friend dedicated to ocean conservation and denies she is a flight risk.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's case; this letter is submitted to her in support of Maxwell's bail application.

events.title: Family Visit to Maxwell's Manhattan Home
events.description: The writer and their family visited Ghislaine Maxwell at her home in Manhattan, where she was noted to be busy with philanthropic ocean conservation work.

events.title: Death of Ghislaine Maxwell's Mother
events.description: The letter mentions that Ghislaine Maxwell's mother died in 2013.

events.title: Submission of Bail Support Letter
events.description: Date the character reference letter is written and submitted to Judge Nathan in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's bail application.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: A friend offers to sign a $5 million bond for Ghislaine Maxwell's bail, stating that losing it would cause financial ruin, indicating strong personal belief in her compliance.
The writer describes Ghislaine Maxwell as a principled, disciplined woman dedicated to ocean conservation work, including presentations at the UN and TED talks.
The letter explicitly rejects media claims that Maxwell was in hiding from law enforcement, asserting she simply wanted to prepare her defense appropriately.
The writer has known Maxwell since 1979, when she was a student preparing for Oxford University, and details a long-standing personal and family friendship.
